user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_monotonic_sec_counter:
```c
time_t
MHD_monotonic_sec_counter (void)
{
#ifdef HAVE_CLOCK_GETTIME
  struct timespec ts;

  if ( (_MHD_UNWANTED_CLOCK != mono_clock_id) &&
       (0 == clock_gettime (mono_clock_id,
                            &ts)) )
    return ts.tv_sec - mono_clock_start;
#endif /* HAVE_CLOCK_GETTIME */
#ifdef HAVE_CLOCK_GET_TIME
  if (_MHD_INVALID_CLOCK_SERV != mono_clock_service)
  {
    mach_timespec_t cur_time;

    if (KERN_SUCCESS == clock_get_time (mono_clock_service,
                                        &cur_time))
      return cur_time.tv_sec - mono_clock_start;
  }
#endif /* HAVE_CLOCK_GET_TIME */
#if defined(_WIN32)
#if _WIN32_WINNT >= 0x0600
  if (1)
    return (time_t) (((uint64_t) (GetTickCount64 () - tick_start)) / 1000);
#else  /* _WIN32_WINNT < 0x0600 */
  if (0 != perf_freq)
  {
    LARGE_INTEGER perf_counter;

    QueryPerformanceCounter (&perf_counter);   /* never fail on XP and later */
    return (time_t) (((uint64_t) perf_counter.QuadPart - perf_start)
                     / perf_freq);
  }
#endif /* _WIN32_WINNT < 0x0600 */
#endif /* _WIN32 */
#ifdef HAVE_GETHRTIME
  if (1)
    return (time_t) (((uint64_t) (gethrtime () - hrtime_start)) / 1000000000);
#endif /* HAVE_GETHRTIME */

  return time (NULL) - sys_clock_start;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_monotonic_sec_counter:
static time_t mono_clock_start
...
static clockid_t mono_clock_id = _MHD_UNWANTED_CLOCK
...
#define _MHD_UNWANTED_CLOCK CLOCK_REALTIME
...
static time_t sys_clock_start
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Rule 21.14 forbids using the standard library function memcmp to compare null-terminated strings. I examined the provided function MHD_monotonic_sec_counter and the related symbol definitions. The code contains only time-related system/library calls (clock_gettime, clock_get_time, GetTickCount64, QueryPerformanceCounter, gethrtime, time), integer arithmetic and integer/macro comparisons, and no string handling. There is no use of memcmp, no other string-comparison functions, and no comparisons of null-terminated strings in the shown code or the provided related definitions. Therefore there are no code fragments that need investigation for Rule 21.14.
